content.body: Lachy_: do you know if any Opera preview builds support Selecotrs API?
(or does anyone else know?)
hi roc
hi
othermaciej: I am pretty sure that the Selectors API has not been implemented in Opera yet, even in snapshot builds
MikeSmith: ok, thanks
I'm writing up what was new in WebKit 3.1 and I want to mention which things are supported in other browsers.
othermaciej: as far as things supported in other browsers, I believe the details in my XTech presentation are accurate (though I didn't bother to record citations)
though I made on update to that since I did the presentation
I added the fact that Mozilla/FF3 now supports the AppCache API
which I didn't know until I read Mark Finkle's blog posting about it a few days ago
MikeSmith: I am testing as needed
fucking openoffice
tries hard to think of how any office suite could possibly be worse than openoffice
great way to completely lock up my whole machine
MikeSmith: it could not exist, for one
openoffice should show a big warning every time you start it up: Don't be stupid enough to actually try to use this application to do anything useful.
those guys should be ashamed of themselves with that thin
I wouldn't go that far; on the other hand, I don't think it's something they can be especially proud of
OpenOffice gets something like ten billion dollars less revenue each year than Microsoft Office, so it's not surprising that it doesn't work quite so well
I don't use MS Office at all, so I don't really care how it compares. I just need it to work without it causing me to lose data and waste time
it just should not be advertised as being stable and ready for production use
because it's not
used Word much?

because I used to write papers in Word, and I kept running into this bug where Word would replace one of my figures with a big red X while it was repaginating. Apparently that bug has/had been around for years and years.
roc: sounds pretty annoying
I don't use Word, ever
not for years now at least
OK
but yeah, when I did I can remember running into many bugs
I'm just saying that Word has pretty bad bugs. It seems everyone got used to them.

yeah, and/or figures out workarounds and uses those and eventually forgets there was a bug because they just use the workarounds. that's the problem with this kind of stuff -- it forces you to alter the way you use the app, to the point where you eventually don't even realize it
right.
it's a big barrier to entry
I just find that working with any kind of office app is a huge time-waster.. end up needing to spend time trying to make all kinds of formatting tweaks
ok, well, for you there's emacs and Latex :-)
heh
I usually try to stick to HTML and generate PDFs from that when needed
using Prince or something
latex is a far worse time waster than an office app -- soo many ways to tweak stuff to be more semantic, change display characteristics, etc.
wow, sam missed the point of your case #3
i don't understand people's obsession with generic syntax extensibility
given how small a part of the puzzle syntax is
I'm not sure why distributed extensibility is seen as necessarily a work item that should be taken up by the HTML WG
instead of by the CDF WG
or the XMLWG
oh wait they already solved it!
well
gah
I can't remember what confidentiality level my information is
w3c information?
oh
http://www.w3.org/2007/11/CDF_rechartering/CDF-proposed
> Given the recent activity in non-XML HTML, the CDF WG will devote attention to inclusion of other languages in HTML as well as XHTML.
haha
good times
now they can be pointless and ineffectual in twice as many syntaxes

Hixie: do you remember when and why the "The HTML WG is encouraged to provide a mechanism to permit independently developed vocabularies such as Internationalization Tag Set (ITS), Ruby, and RDFa to be mixed into HTML documents." language was added to the draft charter?
also, noting "Tim Berners-Lee described this incorporation of SVG and MathML without namespaces as horrific and the issue raiser completely concurs with the him." --
noting that, it seems like what this issue should really have been titled is "Adding support for namespaces text/html"
because that's effectively what it amounts to
MikeSmith: because my advice was ignored and some of the architectural astronauts got their way, i imagine
i think it's telling that no web app provider, and no web browser vendor, has asked for this feature
I think it is telling that no large content providers or normal users have either
Hixie: what feature?
(I guess I should read the logs)
namespaces
oh, CDF
oh, namespaces
in text/html
CDF WG has not been very successful in engaging UA vendors
their main successes are writing down the obvious conclusions of other specs
i was on the CDF WG
i quit when i realised the group was clueless and doing pointless work
I mentioned CDF just because it seems to me the group that is actually explicitly chartered to work on this very thing
unlike the HTML WG, whose charter just says the group is "encouraged" to provide a mechanism for it
and just as an aside, it's odd the degree to which some advocates of this have gone to avoid mentioning namespaces
e.g., the HTML WG charter itself says "Whether this occurs through the extensibility mechanism of XML"
MikeSmith: what the htmlwg charter says doesn't much matter to me in the context of this channel :-)
my humor/sarcasm/troll/seriousness detector is completely malfunctioning when it comes to the "move semantics into attributes" thread
hsivonen: pretty sure he's being honest
hsivonen, I think in theory we can get away with two formats
If XML5 requires a new media type and all I'm not sure it's worth it
annevk: yeah, I should have rethought the point before replying.
i hope someone sends a detailed reply to the e-mail justin sent me, because i don't want to do it :-P
Hixie, for the response headers, do you remember how you ended up with the whitelist?
which one?
for getResponseHeader
"Cache-Control, Content-Language, Content-Type, Expires, Last-Modified, or Pragma"
i came up with that?
i probably looked at the spec and decided which were useful and safe
near the bottom of http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-webapi/2006Jun/0012.html
i wonder if it should be a blacklist instead
just like we have for setRequestHeader()
blacklists are bad
as a general rule
from a security standpoint
true
maybe it's not so bad to limit this to just this
I read Joe Clark writing that the WCAG specifiers struggled with machine-checkability until realizing that their problem domain needs human checking
I wonder if there are citable sources for this other than Joe's inflammatorily titled ALA article
didn't he also state that the group was "dominated" by automatic accessibility checker companies?
IIRC something along those lines
a whitelist is certainly less risky
finds it hard to believe Justin James' proposal is serious.
curl: (6) Couldn't resolve host 'html5.validator.nu'
that seems bad
Hixie: resolves for me from two autonomous systems

hsivonen, re your email subject example, good mail clients warn before sending an email without a subject because most of the time it happens, it's an accidental omission that the sender would prefer to fix
Lachy: but the reason they prefer to fix it isn't on a spec's sayso but because they need it for communicating with the people they are seeking to communicate with
although, some insert something like (no subject) by default
ok
experience suggests that people write bad subjects if they are new to email or if they know they are in a position of power so that recipients will want to read the email based on sender name
now the problem accessibility advocates have is that alt is for the benefit of a third party when the author seeks to communicate in images with someone who will consume the images

FWIW, I often write bad subjects when e.g. emailing friends as the content of the mail is often just a collection of miscellany rather than one specific topic (and, honestly, I hope they would read it in any case ;) )
Mailing lists are a different audience and so are treated differently
jgraham_: I guess that falls under the case of getting read due to sender identity even if not necessarily due to a position of power
hsivonen: Yeah
on high volume mailing lists, sometimes it's easier to read based on sender identity than based on the subject, especially when some people are known to write nonsense
Lachy: yeah. for instance, i never read your emails. ;)
hah
mean
that's fine. I know some subscribers on some mailing lists who only read mine and a few others ;-)
hsivonen: I just used validator.nu for the sake of blind conformance badge value; please forgive me
othermaciej: was the quality of your markup improved as a result?
hsivonen: not really, I just replaced spaces in some img src attributes with %20
was HyTime ever deployed anywhere?
what is HyTime?
spaces in should be allowed
either IRIs need to be cleaned up or this concept Hixie introduced but did not define should do it
HTML would have to make URI attribute values not be URIs in that case
(or IRIs)
it would just be some pre-processing
annevk: might slip through authoring mistakes in the form of misquoting
although now that " is not allowed in attribute names (and some other such checks), perhaps misquoted attributes would be catched anyway
othermaciej: HyTime is an ISO hypertext system based on SGML
literal space will work interoperably in attribute values of course, but not in many other URI contexts (if only because the space breaks attempts to autodetect them in text)
so I don't feel too bad about that requirement
on the other hand, I think it made my html less readable to use %20
and these are relative URIs in any case
the biggest problem with spaces in href=""s that i've seen is that they risk getting wordwrapped
and then who knows what'll happen
http://xml.coverpages.org/hytimeKimber9701.html
look for the paragraph starting with 'Technicaly, HyTime is an "enabling architecture".'
HyTime is also a market failure.
i wonder if there's a correlation
"it provides a set of 'meta-element types' that serve as templates or supertypes from which you derive your own element types with their own element type names and specialized attributes"
sounds sweet, sign me up
but it sounds like I should bring my space helmet
Hixie: do you have any reason why I shouldn't offer an option to get warnings whenever tags are inferred?
none other than the usual "options are bad ui" thing
if people want to be told when they use that syntax feature, then they should be able to obtain that information
yeah. I'm told I don't need to put it in the HTML5 UI as long as there's a magic bookmarkable URI parameter
the reasoning is that not having this feature is claimed to be an important evangelism blocker when advocating HTML5 to the XHTML-as-text/html crowd
hsivonen: I threw something at it with some (unintentional) errors and it seems to me the error recovery is not yet very good
othermaciej: 'it' being Validator.nu?
I forgot the close quote on some attributes
hsivonen: yeah
othermaciej: do you mean the recovery was bad or that the messages were bad?
(the recovery is per spec)
I mean that it gave lots of error messages for what was actually one mistake, and they created so much noise I could not spot my second mistake until I fixed the first
this is a UI complaint, not a standards compliance complaint
ok.

there seem to be two issues: 1) what the tokenizer spec says are errors (normative) and 2) how I phrase the errors (not normative; now phrased according to tokenization situation--not according to the probable user intent)
the old behavior with < breaking out of a tag and starting a new one was more intuitive
I wonder if it were worthwhile to stop reporting errors until there has been one transition to the data state
that would seem bad for general purpose perf and for Java byte code size, though...
the spec only requires that you report one error if there is one and none if there are none, right?
spaces in URIs are problematic for ping= I guess
Hixie: yeah. but on the other hand, when I opt to stop reporting errors, people complain that the parser didn't keep on trucking
hsivonen: well i just mean that you don't have to report exactly the right errors, if there are more useful ones you can report
does the spec require that if a conformance checker recovers from errors, it must report the same errors that the parsing algorithm would flag?
it seems to me that for usability's sake it's probably not good for the exact set of errors reported to be a normative requirement
I'm not sure, actually. It does require recovery to be per spec
since quality of error messages should be a potential point of competition

Conformance checkers must report at least one parse error condition to the user if one or more parse error conditions exist in the document and must not report parse error conditions if none exist in the document. Conformance checkers may report more than one parse error condition if more than one parse error conditions exist in the document. Conformance checkers are not required to recover from parse errors.
i can change the last sentence to allow arbitrary error recovery if you like

though in this particular case highlighting the likely actual authoring error and having the detailed error messages available in a distinguished form (indented, smaller text, disclosure triangle, something like that) would probably have been good enough
decides to run random pages on webkit.org through validator.nu
hmm the blog looks better than I thought
wrong doctype and it doesn't like the feed: URIs, and hyatt apparently would rather type <tt> than <code>
othermaciej: hyatt should use his editorship to make <tt> conforming :-)
is <tt> commonly used?
bed time
nn
nn
Lachy: http://canvex.lazyilluminati.com/survey/2007-07-17/analyse.cgi/tag/tt
vs http://canvex.lazyilluminati.com/survey/2007-07-17/analyse.cgi/tag/code
vs http://canvex.lazyilluminati.com/survey/2007-07-17/analyse.cgi/tag/samp etc
ouch. I may have missed conformance checking-relevant spec updates between 1478 and 1495
(i.e. <tt> is on 30 pages out of 7739)
(and you can decide on your own definition of "common" and whether <tt> counts)
that's on more than <code>
yay. no changes annotated [c] in that range
one of those uses of <tt> is to create an invisible line spacer
on http://www.moytura.com/westport.htm
I should not be surprised I guess yet somehow I am
also a surprising number of these pages are in Polish
webkit.org homepage, the only error as html5 is the doctype
http://validator.w3.org/check?uri=http%3A%2F%2Fwebkit.org%2F&charset=%28detect+automatically%29&doctype=Inline&group=0
Philip`: I'm forcing HTML5 mode
oh hmm
Shouldn't duplicate IDs be an HTML5 error too?
yes
&group=0 ?
hsivonen: That's just what it adds when I click the Check button
and it is definitely a duplicate id
hsivonen: does validator.nu have a bug tracker?
ok, found the bugzilla
Philip`: that's weird
Philip`: oh. sorry. it was w3.org
hsivonen: http://bugzilla.validator.nu/show_bug.cgi?id=184
othermaciej: http://bugzilla.validator.nu/show_bug.cgi?id=149
darn, I thought I might have the first bug not filed by hsivonen
(it looks like there are some others anyway, so I am not too sad that it's a dupe)
wow, Node.lookupNamespaceURI has got some major interoperability issues :-(
Hixie: wrt setting reflecting booleans, it appears that IE and Opera have switched behavior with each other since last time I tested :-)
Hixie: but safari and firefox still use the empty string
what's the difference between "cognitively impaired [user]" and "user with intellectual disabilities"?
hsivonen, cognitive impairments can include memory loss, emotional difficulties, mental health problems, the whole buffet of brain-related issues
hsivonen, intellectual disabilities isn't a term I've heard before but I imagine it's more specific...literacy and communication perhaps
alt madness continues :(
The only way to resolve it is with a duel
I shouldn't have jumped into it

re: the current alt discussion, it seems to me it's important to ascertain and distinguish between what UA+AT currently do (for backwards compatibility purposes) and what UA+AT should do (for ideal conformance).
othermaciej and Faulkner are, AFAICT, both right. repetition is unwanted but differing navigational strategies may require a certain level of repetition in existing UA+AT.

othermaciej: You mention how skipping the image might be useful for verbal output; I'm not sure that's necessarily the case (what about when you need to discover the image?), but in any case it seems to be something verbal UA+AT could implement using the proposed markup.
e.g. skip the alt given when reading straight through the page.

It's rather like the problem with link context, which is crucial when not navigating the page linearly, but potentially distracting when you do: http://lists.whatwg.org/htdig.cgi/whatwg-whatwg.org/2008-March/014258.html
webben: I don't see how the proposed markup would let you know that you can skip the alt
webben: I'm also not sure why navigating to the image has to be even available as an option, to a user consuming purely text

othermaciej: If the aria-described-by or longdesc or whatever is defined as pointing to a full text alternative, and that alternative is in the current document, then the UA knows its reading the image alternative.
for a visually impaired but not blind user, or a cognitively disabled user, supplemental info would better expressed as title=""
othermaciej: Navigating to images is important because images are content, and the user may wish to save the image/share it with others/edit it etc etc etc
webben: surely the same could be said for decorative images, and in that case alt="" is considered acceptable and will skip the image in many configurations
othermaciej: decorative images aren't content; alt="" is fine.
(yes, conceivably users might want access to decorative images, or CSS background-images, in both cases viewing or inspecting the source seems appropriate.)
visual UAs don't prevent users from saving decorative images, sharing them with others, or editing them (once saved)
it's kind of annoying when you're implementing a spec that has been implemented at least three times already and there are still basic ambiguities in the spec
neither do non-visual UAs.
the point is what's most useful to be alerted to.
othermaciej: OK, I _will_ use yacc (actually, I'll use PLY)
then I don't see why alt="" is ok for a decorative image but not for a non-decorative but redundant-with-the-text image
roc: what spec?
because content is much more fundamental to general human communication and sharing than decorative images?
saving an image is not the common operation; you don't normally need to be alerted to it
unless for some reason screen reader users are much more likely to save images, which I grant is not impossible (don't really know)

saving an image is only one of the scenarios I mentioned, but like I said: "You mention how skipping the image might be useful for verbal output; I'm not sure that's necessarily the case (what about when you need to discover the image?), but in any case it seems to be something verbal UA+AT could implement using the proposed markup."
SVG flters, this time
lots of SVG has basic ambiguities in the spec
hardly specific to filters
well yeah
what's actually best for default behavior is perhaps best left to user testing by the UA+AT vendors and developers.
I didn't say I was surprised :-)
but you'd think they would have discovered interop problems and fixed the spec
maybe there's a graphics programmer mindset that makes them all take the same decisions
webben: so you don't subscribe to the "behavior of current AT will never change, therefore the spec must cater to it" school of thought?

othermaciej: The spec needs to cater to the behavior of current AT as a matter of backwards compatibility (it does this generally for browsers, and it's more important for AT because it does more harm to individuals who are locked into expensive AT if it doesn't); I think it also needs to look forward to the improvement of AT.
"cater" here does not necessarily mean "optimise for"
roc: There's quite a lot of bits in the canvas spec too, where the spec says pretty much nothing but everyone implements it the same way anyway
(e.g. how you draw a stroked line)
unfortunately if you try to specify that too much you will kill performance
and I don't know if it's worth adding the necessary large amounts of complexity to the spec to describe precisely how to implement these things
webben: to me, speaking duplicate content seems like a pretty bad bug (perhaps as bad as occasionally reading gibberish filenames)
webben: and it is a bug that would occur in all existing and near-term foreseeable UA+AT combinations
what's "near-term" here?
further, if this changes in some assistive technologies over time, this makes life harder for designers who actually want to create a good experience for e.g. screen reader users
there are probably few who care to the point of going beyond a simple checklist, and probably even fewer who test with one or more screen readers
so maybe that's not so important
/if/ it's a bug, I don't see why the implementation couldn't change to skip alt in certain situations, well, tomorrow e.g. with a commit to Orca or NVDA.
I'd love to work on a project that could give consistent one-day turnaround even just for simple bugs
You've never seen a bug fixed in one day on WebKit?
I've seen plenty fixed in one day, a few one day after being reported, a tiny handful where that happend and the fix did not cause a regression, and 0 where the fix was shipped to end users that day
bugs get fixed in one day, but only a very small portion of them
a commit to Orca/NVDA != "fix was shipped to end users"
that's why I said "consistent one-day turnaround"
I mean a source commit.
sure, some things could get fixed in one day, but very few things will and it is hard to control which
othermaciej, would a DOMStringMap, which is partially defined in HTML5, work for the NSResolver?
it'd be much easier if you could forego reviews, but that has its own problems :-)
if there were a way for authors to create one.
Lachy: DOMStringMap looks like a spec for an implementation object with magical name lookup rules, not for a convenient author-provided static data map
yeah, I guess.
for webkit we mandate reviews, passing all the tests, adding a regression test for any behavior change, and performance testing, but some things still manage to get fixed in a day
not many though!
Is {'html':'http://...', 'svg':'http://...'} not an adequate convenient author-provided static data map?
and accessibility is an area that is so far lacking in regression testing in WebKit so scarier to work on

Philip`: Bjoern objected to it on the basis of (a) setters reintroducing possibility of random code execution (I say ignore them) (b) not scaling to non-JS languages (I don't care) and (c) not having an obvious way to represent the default namespace
I don't think you can name a JS property the empty string, but you could probably come up with a name that is not a valid namespace prefix and reasonably conveys defaultness
(perhaps '_' would do)
Firefox seems happy enough with {'':1}
Philip`, that can't work because of getters { get svg() { doSomething(); return "..." };
Lachy: Is it not possible to just define it to ignore getters?
If the property has a getter and is not just a raw value, then throw an exception or something, except express that in crazy ECMAScript notation with lots of double-square-brackets
s/If/Or if/
ah, right, I meant getters, not setters
the other solution that was suggested on public-webapi was to use a string like this "xht=http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml svg=http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
ES3 doesn't have getters per spec, ES4 may or may not have an in-language way to bypass them, the implementation can bypass in any case if it wants to
the string is syntacally nicer than all the JS Object stuff, and it also doesn't suffer from any compatibility issues in non-ECMAScript langauges
othermaciej: If there is no way for users to to bypass them, could implementations optimise the objects by not storing the hidden-by-getter properties at all?
(which would break if there were special cases in the DOM that did require them to be bypassed)
but I still need to check with Opera developer internally to see what they think of each solution
Philip`: what hidden-by-getter properties?
a property is either a regular property or it is programmatic
can't be both
othermaciej: Ah, okay
othermaciej: When you say "bypass", does that mean just detecting whether the property is regular or programmatic, as opposed to bypassing the getter in order to get at a regular property behind it?
Philip`: right, I mean getter properties are ignored for purposes of building the prefix mapping table
I think the string might be better though
certainly simplifies things specwise
though having to parse it will add maybe a tiny bit of overhead
Hixie: is there a suggested file extension for cache manifests
doesn't see anything particularly onerous about a function, fw (little) iw
but then again, I wouldn't touch namespaces if I could help it anyway, so I'm not the target audience
grmbl
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2008May/0228.html is pretty useless
he completely quotes Dave Singer out of context and then goes on with his alt= should be mandatory meme
they should really stop with their rhetoric and come with arguments...
Lachy: FWIW I think the string NSResolver is uglier than the object
why?
Hixie?
andersca: .manifest, i guess
Hixie: OK!
Hixie: from reading section 4.8, point 7 it seems that a resource can be stored in one or more application caches even if the browsing context is not associated with a cache
"We need to nail @alt to the mast!" ... "I keep an open mind"
@annevk and the rest of the people taking time to discuss it, you have my sympathy :)
jgraham_, Philip`: Do either of you know how common it is to change from Comp.Sci. to Nat.Sci. at the end of first year, especially among those who only did one science at a-level/equiv.?

andersca: yeah, if a.html and b.html both reference different manifests that put c.html into their cache, then when you navigate to c.html, it'll be in two caches. But if in those caches it doesn't have a manifest="" attribute, then the document will first be loaded from one of those caches, and then the UA will realise it doesn't have a matching manifest, and will reload it from the network.

Lachy: Because the string isn't such a natural representation of the datatype which is basically a set of (key, value) pairs. Working with a string in code is harder than working with a structure that maps naturally onto the actual data. Also namespace URIs tend to be long and breaking a string over multiple lines is harder than doing the same with an object or other data structure  it's less likely that an IDE will have good indentatio
n for example.
Hixie: but also if the URL of c.html matches an opportunistically cached namespace
Hixie: right?
gsnedders: Not off the top of my head
jgraham_: looking on cam.ac.uk, it lists Maths & Phys. and Comp.Sci. as the two other routes into Nat.Sci. second year, but I can see no more

gsnedders: Which version of CS? I believe the 25% option is for people who expect to continue into NatSci after the first year, while the 50% one is for people who expect to stay with CS, and I think they're adding the 75% soon for crazy people who really like CS
Basically if you want to do Physics + Maths Nat. Sci. in IB (second year) and you did reasonably well in 1A Physics/Maths no one will care about anything else
Philip`: I see only one on the website :P

andersca: if you're offline, and you try to load a page as a fallback page for a top-level browsing context and it doesn't have a manifest="" matching the cache's manifest, then the load will be canceled and the browsing context will instead show an inline error message
Philip`: 50% it seems to be
jgraham_: Is it possible to do entirely physics in IB?
gsnedders: For you 50% Comp. Sci. + Maths B + Physics seems right for the first year
(I think Maths B is the harder one)

andersca: it is impossible for a page load to complete (or even get past the <html> implied start tag) in a top-level browsing context without there being an <html> start tag with a manifest="" pointing to the manifest of the cache from which it was loaded
Philip`: Yeah, you're basically expected to
Then I have the fun of choosing a college to apply to :P
Hixie: if I'm online, and load a page from the network and its url matches an opportunistic namespace
Hixie: then that page needs to be stored regardless of whether the browsing context is associated with a cache or not
(I think technically the courses are Physics and Advanced Physics but few people do one and not the other)
(at least people who carry on with Physics in Pt II, and few people do IB physics but not Pt II physics)
(As I said on Friday, I don't meet the entrance requirements for Nat.Sci., so I can't apply for it (well, I can, it's just pointless))

gsnedders: The http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/admissions/undergraduate/intro/ site? That seems unclearer when I last looked, but it's mostly talking about what I'd call 50% and the "Alternative first year option" is 25%

gsnedders: The important thing about applying to a college is to remember that the criteria that you would apply in retrospect have little correlation with the information that is avaliable before you apply
Philip`: http://www.cam.ac.uk/admissions/undergraduate/courses/compsci/index.html
jgraham_: I'm aware. I should probably try and get criteria off my sister (who went to Selwyn)
Her reasons were silly :P
andersca: hm yeah, step 7 of the navigate steps is broken
Philip`: That alternate option seems to be doing Nat.Sci. as a main subject, so applying for it, I think
The hard and fast rule is do not, under any circumstances, go with the "no preference" option
Hixie: for performance reasons it seems bad to do this :)
jgraham_: I've heard that time and time again, and quite frankly, I don't want to :)
My criteria involved excluding colleges that were too far away, and excluding ones with names that sounded silly, etc, and then picking semi-arbitrarily from those that were left

andersca: it's also broken in that if you try to fetch something that's oppcached and you get a 404, then you'll use the fallback, but if the fallback doesn't have a correct manifest="", it'll loop as it tries to use the network again
Hixie: good point
My sister wanted somewhere which could accommodate her for her entire degree, and taught a fair amount of it on site.
Philip`: That sounds quite like my criteria. Although I was also heavilly influenced by the fact that Jesus isn't on the tourist trail and had a sculpture exhibition on when I went to look around
andersca: can you send mail?
Philip`: Would you, in retrospective, say King's was good?
Hixie: yes
andersca: thanks
andersca: woul it be helpful to you if i went and did appcache stuff next?
gsnedders: I think everywhere has accommodation for the whole degree now
King's has the (seemingly quite rare) advantage of not having any stupid network restrictions, though I don't know if they'll change in the future
Hixie: I thought you already did :)
Having a tutor for you subject is a good idea
jgraham_: Well, my sister applied in '91 (before I was born)
andersca: well you're about to send new feedback :-)
Hixie: ah :)
Hixie: I do have some feedback regarding dynamic entries too
Philip`: what sort of restrictions?
there's apparently 19 e-mails in my appcache pile
jgraham_: you know anywhere where you could find that, apart from just nagging each college?
mostly stuff from public-html
so probably not useful
for you
